action: I want to precisely control executable operations for each user
reason: To prevent data leakage and operational errors, and to comply with internal controls and security policies
acceptance_criteria: The permission management function is only operable by the Administrator role.
Multiple roles can be created.
Role IDs must be unique.
Permission settings can be configured on a per-function basis for each role.
Functional permissions can be set for 'View/Create/Update/Delete' units.
Access permission settings on a per-API basis are possible.
Control over menu visibility is possible.
Data range control (e.g., restricted to own department) is possible.
Users can belong to multiple roles.
Priority rules for roles can be defined.
Permission changes are reflected immediately.
Re-authentication is required if a logged-in user's permissions are changed.
Access is prohibited for functions where no permissions are set.
Unauthorized access attempts return a 403 Forbidden error.
Permission checks must be executed on the backend.
Control restricted only to the frontend side is prohibited.
Permission information is cached.
Cache updates are automatically reflected upon changes.
Permission change history is stored.
Change history stores values before and after the change.
The ID of the user performing the change is recorded.
Permission change operations are recorded in the audit log.
Role deletion is a logical delete.
Deletion history is stored.
Deleted roles cannot be newly assigned.
SQL injection countermeasures are implemented.
Input values are sanitized (Anti-XSS).
The same validation applies to permission changes via API.
Authentication is mandatory for API access.
Rate limiting is applied to the API.
Permission data is stored with encryption.
Authentication is mandatory for internal system-to-system communication.
Alerts occur upon detection of permission inconsistencies.
An export function for permission settings exists.
An import function for permission settings exists.
A role template function exists.
Initial settings are provided based on the Principle of Least Privilege.
An automatic role deactivation function for retired users exists.
Operations are rejected upon permission policy violations.
The design ensures permission checks do not delay even under high load.
Audit logs are stored in tamper-evident storage.
